"In January, Greek voters gave power to the left-wing Syriza party, one third of which, The Economist reports, consists of “Maoists, Marxists and supporters of Che Guevara.” Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras, 40, a retired student radical, immediately denounced a European Union declaration criticizing Russia’s dismemberment of Ukraine. He chose only one Cabinet member with prior government experience — a leader of Greece’s Stalinist Communist party.

Doesn't Greece owe this money? Shouldn't it be trying to pay it back? I mean I don't mean to sound ignorant, but when you go into a bank and they ask you to do all of these things in order to borrow money, don't you sort of need to do what they ask? I mean it is different if they didn't need the money, but through bad choices this is where they are now at, right? So isn't it their job now to sober up and deal with the consequences now that the party's over?

Tsipras faces added pressure from Greece's public servants, who are being called to stage a 24-hour strike on Wednesday.
Their union, Adedy, called for the stoppage in a statement issued on Monday, saying it was to show their opposition to the outline agreement with the eurozone.
It will also urge the civil servants to take part in a demonstration against the reforms scheduled to take place in front of parliament late Wednesday.

This will be the first strike to happen under Tsipras, the head of the left-wing Syriza bloc. <a href="http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2015/07/greece-bailout-deal-sparks-domestic-opposition-150713182015462.html" target="_blank">http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2015/0...182015462.html</a>
